events.speaker: host
events.text: Welcome to SkillStream Originals.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Tonight: a skill that builds a website to publish your skills. Skillception.

events.speaker: host
events.text: It's not magic. It's a checklist. Which is basically magic for adults.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: So you're telling me the skill ships a show... about the skill?

events.speaker: host
events.text: Exactly. It's documentation, but with a budget of two polygons.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: As long as the installer refuses to run if Codex is not initialized, I sleep.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: And updates? Please tell me updates are boring and safe.

events.speaker: host
events.text: VERSION plus tags. Backups on upgrade. The thrill is unmatched.

events.speaker: host
events.text: For the public site: no runtime voice API calls. You can replay this episode without spending anyone's credits.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: So it's like: you publish a skill, and the skill publishes the skill publisher. That feels illegal in three jurisdictions.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Relax. It's two repos. One public for the skill folder. One usually private for the website source, deployed publicly.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: Private repo, public site. Like a kitchen. You don't need to see my cabinets to taste the soup.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: Is the soup SemVer flavored? Because I only eat versions with three numbers.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Yes: SemVer, Keep a Changelog, and a secret scan so you don't accidentally publish a .env and your dignity.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: If you paste an API key into chat, it's considered compromised. Rotate it. Do not argue with the robot.

events.speaker: host
events.text: We even give you a short installer: curl to /install.sh or iwr to /install.ps1. Same command updates later.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: A one-liner that updates itself. Finally, a relationship where someone actually changes when they promise.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: Okay, I'm in. But explain CODEX_HOME like I'm five and my terminal is judging me.

events.speaker: host
events.text: CODEX_HOME is just the folder Codex uses for skills and auth. Default is ~/.codex on macOS or %USERPROFILE%\.codex on Windows.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: And if you moved it? Set CODEX_HOME. Otherwise the installer will refuse and politely blame you.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: Installers refusing politely is my love language. 'Error: you're not ready for commitment.'

events.speaker: host
events.text: The gate checks four things: the folder exists, skills/ exists, auth.json exists, and the built-in installer script exists.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: That last one is my favorite. 'I can't install skills unless I can prove you know how to install skills.'

events.speaker: ops
events.text: It's not recursion. It's safety. Also: it prevents installing into a random folder you'll never use.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Once it passes, it downloads the public skill repo zip, extracts, and copies only the skill folder into CODEX_HOME/skills.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: So the website isn't downloaded. Just the skill. Like ordering a cookbook and not receiving the entire restaurant.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: And if it's already installed?

events.speaker: ops
events.text: Then it says it's up to date. Or it upgrades: backs up the old folder, installs the new one, and rolls back if anything fails.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Flags exist for power users: FORCE=1 to repair, KEEP_BACKUP=1 to keep the .bak folder. Normal people: just rerun the command.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: Normal people also rerun commands. We just call it 'turning it off and on again'.

events.speaker: host
events.text: On the website, we simulate real terminal output: success, Codex missing, not initialized, custom CODEX_HOME, update available.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: And we match the real scripts exactly. If the demo lies, I personally will file an issue against the demo.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: Speaking of issues: support is just GitHub Issues, right? No email chain that starts with 'per my last message'.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Exactly. Public skill repo for issues and releases. Website repo can be private. The site links always point to the public one.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: So the docs are public, the source is private, and my mistakes are forever. Cool.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Now, the part that makes maintainers nervous: a streaming-style player embedded in every generated site.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: Not affiliated with any streaming service. No trademarks. No borrowed sounds. Only vibes.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: Vibes are legally distinct from branding. It's like saying: 'I didn't copy it, I just arrived at the same idea wearing a different hat.'

events.speaker: host
events.text: The episode is pre-generated and shipped as static files: mp3, script.json, and captions in nine languages.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: No runtime voice API calls. No exposed keys. That key you pasted into chat? Rotate it. I'm not kidding.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: And if credits run out, we don't panic. The site keeps playing the existing episode. Comedy is cached.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Want rewatch? Hit Play once, and the service worker caches /show/* so it can replay smoothly even on flaky networks.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: A service worker is basically a bouncer for your bandwidth. 'You're on the list. Go in. No new downloads tonight.'

events.speaker: ops
events.text: We even support Range requests from cache, so scrubbing works offline. I wrote that line so I could feel something.

events.speaker: host
events.text: And for people who hate magic: there's a Save offline button. It downloads and pins the episode in browser storage.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: So the show is installed like a skill: you watch it once, and it quietly lives in your house forever.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Exactly. And when you publish your own skill site, you can swap in your own pilot. New cast. New jokes. Same template.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: Please keep the jokes original. If I see 'Season 1: The API Key', I'm calling legal.

events.speaker: friend2
events.text: So the skill makes a website, the website installs the skill, and the skill can publish itself. Does the universe collapse?

events.speaker: host
events.text: Only if you forget to bump VERSION. Then time itself refuses to move forward.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: And if you do bump it, you tag a release with the same number. VERSION equals tag equals release. We keep reality consistent.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: Meanwhile, the installer reads that VERSION and upgrades me automatically. So I'm basically a package manager with feelings.

events.speaker: host
events.text: You're all package managers with feelings. That's the whole show.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Back on stage: if you're new, here's the pitch. Choose a skill folder. Press publish. You get a site, installers, docs, and deploy previews.

events.speaker: friend1
events.text: Deploy previews from PRs. The only kind of preview that has ever improved my self-esteem.

events.speaker: ops
events.text: And when the installer refuses, it's not being rude. It's protecting you from installing into nowhere. Run Codex once. Then rerun.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Good night. Tip your maintainers. And may your auth.json always exist where you think it is.

events.speaker: host
events.text: End credits: made with templates, not trademarks.

events.speaker: host
events.text: Thanks for watching.
